title: New evidence on the effects of US monetary policy on exchange rates

references.title: Are foreign exchange intervention and monetary policy related, and does it really matter?,
references.raw: Lewis, K., 1995, Are foreign exchange intervention and monetary policy related, and does it really matter?, Journal of Business 68, 185-214.

references.title: Does monetary policy matter? A new test in the spirit of Friedman
references.raw: Romer, C. and D. Romer, 1989, Does monetary policy matter? A new test in the spirit of Friedman and Schwartz, in: O. Blanchard and S. Fischer, eds., NBER Macroeconomics Annual (MIT Press, Cambridge).

references.title: Expectations and exchange rate dynamics,
references.raw: Dornbusch, R., 1976, Expectations and exchange rate dynamics, Journal of Political Economy 84, 1161-1176.

references.title: Interest rate shocks and the dollar, Economic Perspectives, Federal Reserve Bank of
references.raw: Evans, C., 1994, Interest rate shocks and the dollar, Economic Perspectives, Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago 18, 11-24.

references.title: Interpreting the macroeconomic time series facts: The effects of monetary policy,
references.raw: Sims, C., 1992, Interpreting the macroeconomic time series facts: The effects of monetary policy, European Economic Review 36, 975-1000.

references.title: Measuring monetary policy,
references.raw: Bernanke, B. and I. Mihov, 1998, Measuring monetary policy, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 113, 869-902.

references.title: Monetary policy actions, intervention and exchange rates: A reexamination of the empirical relationships using federal funds rate target data,
references.raw: Bonser-Neal, C., V. Roley and G. Sellon Jr., 1998, Monetary policy actions, intervention and exchange rates: A reexamination of the empirical relationships using federal funds rate target data, Journal of Business 71, 147-177.

references.title: Some empirical evidence on the effects of shocks to monetary policy on exchange rates,
references.raw: Eichenbaum, M. and C. Evans, 1995, Some empirical evidence on the effects of shocks to monetary policy on exchange rates, Quarterly Journal of Economics 110, 975-1009.

references.title: The Federal Funds rate and the channels of monetary policy transmission,
references.raw: Bernanke, B. and A. Blinder, 1992, The Federal Funds rate and the channels of monetary policy transmission, American Economic Review 82, 901-21.

references.title: The identification of monetary policy disturbances: Explaining the liquidity puzzle,
references.raw: Strongin, S., 1995, The identification of monetary policy disturbances: Explaining the liquidity puzzle, Journal of Monetary Economics 35, 463-97.10 TABLE 1. references.title: Μonetary policy shocks: What have we learned and to what end?,
references.raw: Christiano, L., M. Eichenbaum, and C. Evans, 1999, Μonetary policy shocks: What have we learned and to what end?, in: J. Taylor and M. Woodford, eds., Handbook of Macroeconomics, Vol. 1A (North-Holland, Amsterdam) 65-148.

abstract: We examine the impact of US monetary policy shocks on exchange rates using the monetary policy indicator proposed by Bernanke and Mihov [Quarterly Journal of Economics, 113 (1998) 869–902]. We find evidence for instantaneous, rather than delayed, US dollar overshooting after a monetary shock when relative output and relative prices are included in the VAR specification. The forward premium puzzle persists due to the interest rate differential response

We find evidence for instantaneous, rather than delayed, US dollar overshooting after a monetary shock when relative output and relative prices are included in the VAR specification.
